messages: 3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (09:25): hmm. this question had no response in #webkit, so i'll try here.  does anyone know what the proper behavior is for rendering a table where the tbody has a specific height set in css?

3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (09:25): webkit ignores the height, ff2 makes it take up that much space, but leaves rows rendering as they had, ff3 expands rows until they fill up the specified height
3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (09:25): this doesn't seem to really be covered by http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS21/tables.html
3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (09:26): example: http://cs179-spring-2008.seas.harvard.edu/wheatmuffin/prototype/index_2008.04.27-3.html

3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (09:26): if this is unspecified, is there some better way of achieving the same effect?
3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (09:28): opera also seems to ignore it
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:29): iirc 'height' doesn't apply to table sections
3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (09:30): all elements but non-replaced inline elements, table columns, and column groups

3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (09:31): the behavior difference between ff2 and ff3 is also puzzling though

edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (10:46): should there be a way to do in page modal dialogs? like limit all interactivity to a given DOM element and descendents
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (10:48): so you can implement your own menus and such in case the native ones are not good enough

3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (10:50): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: you mean instead of dumping a gigantic invisible un-clickable element over the whole page, then putting the new element w/ a higher z-index?

3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (10:51): but maybe isn't super clean (requires javascript)
